title-group.article-title: A new impulsive synchronization of Chen hyper-chaotic system and Lü hyper-chaotic system

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi’an Jiaotong University, People’s Republic of China
2School of Electrical Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jiakun Zhao, School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, 710049, People’s Republic of China Email: zhaojk@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This work presents an impulsive synchronization scheme of the Chen hyper-chaotic system and Lü hyper-chaotic system with the assumption that all of the parameters are unknown. Sufficient conditions are derived, based on the impulsive differential stability theory, for achieving the impulsive synchronization with the desired scaling factor. By the adaptive control technique, the control laws and the corresponding parameter update laws are obtained such that the impulsive synchronization of the two non-identical hyper-chaotic systems can be realized. Simulation results also illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Since the pioneering work of Pecora and Carroll (1990) in chaos synchronization, it has received a significant attention in the last few years. It has also become an important research topic in mathematics, physics, biological science, chemical reactions, social science, and many other fields. The problem of impulsive synchronization has attracted more attention because this synchronization, known as “impulsive methods”, is much more robust than ever and has higher degree security in secure communication (Sun et al., 2002; Sun and Zhang, 2003; Yang, 2004). In the synchronization process, the response system receives information about the active variables of the drive system only at discrete time instants. The investigation into impulsive synchronization between identically chaotic systems had been presented in Lorenz et al. (2006), Wu et al. (2007) and Hu et al. (2008). In practice, there are many practical examples of impulsive control systems. Three typical examples are a financial system with two state variables of the amount of money in the market and saving rates of a central bank, a chemical reactor system with the quantities of different chemicals serves as states variables, and the insect population control system whose state variables are the number of insects and their natural enemies. Their necessity and importance lie in that, in some cases, the system cannot be controlled by continuous control. Moreover, impulsive control may give a more efficient method to deal with systems that cannot endure continuous disturbance. Additionally, the impulsive method can also greatly reduce the control cost. However, the study of the stability of an impulsive differential equation is much more difficult than that of an ordinary differential equation. A few years ago impulsive control was widely used to stabilize and synchronize chaotic systems. But there are few efficient methods of stabilization and synchronization for this new chaotic system by using impulsive control.

In this paper, a new scheme is proposed for impulsive synchronization between non-identical hyper-chaotic systems. Based on the stability theory of the impulsive differential equation, the impulsive synchronization can be obtained with control laws and the corresponding parameter update laws.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The preliminaries for the stability theory of the impulsive differential equation are provided and the Chen (Lü) hyper-chaotic system is introduced in Section 2. Impulsive synchronization with adaptive control is presented in Section 3. Numerical simulations illustrate the feasibility of this method in Section 4. The conclusion is given in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. Preliminaries
sec.p: To make this paper self-contained and since the theory of impulsive differential equation is not well-known to the scientific community, some basic results are addressed in this section which is useful in the following. These results can be found in these papers (Lakshmikantham et al., 1989; Yang, 2004; Hu et al., 2008).
Consider the general nonlinear system (1)x·=f(t,x) where x=(x1,x2,…,xn)T∈Rn is the state variable, f∈C(R+×Rn,Rn), and x·Δ=dx/dt .

Suppose that a discrete set {τk} of time instants satisfies 0≤τ0<τ1<…<τk<τk+1<…, τk→∞as k→∞. Let (2)δx |t=τk ≡x(τk +)-x(τk -) be the “jump” in the state variable at time instant τk, where x(τk +)=limt→τk +x(t), x(τk -)=limt→τk -x(t). In general, for simplicity, it is assumed that x(τk -)=x(τk). Then, the impulsive control system with the initial condition in time τ0 can be described by (3)x·=f(t,x),t≠τk,δx=Ik(x),t=τk,k=1,2,3,…,x(τ0)=x0, Assumption f(t,0)=0 and Ik(0)=0 for all k .Definition 1:
Let V:R+×Rn→R+, then V is said to belong to class ν0 if
V is continuous in (τk-1,τk]×Rn, and for each x∈Rn,k=1,2,3,…, lim(t,y)→(τk +,x)V(t,y)=V(τk +,x) exists;
V is locally Lipschitzian in x. Definition 2:
For (t,x)∈(τk-1,τk]×Rn, the right and upper Dini’s derivative of V∈ν0 is defined as (4)D+V(t,x)≡limsuph→0+1h[V(t+h,x+hf(f,x))-V(t,x)].
Since the impulsive control system in equation (3) is an nth-order impulsive differential equation, instead of investigating the stability of equation (3), it is convenient to investigate that of a first-order impulsive differential equation which is given by the following comparison system.Definition 3:
Let V∈ν0 and assume that (5)D+V(t,x)≤g(t,V(t,x)),t≠τkV(t,x+Ik(x))≤ψk(V(t,x)),t=τk where g:R+×R+→R is continuous and g(t,0)=0, ψk:R+→R+ is nondecreasing.
Then, the system (6)w·=g(t,w),t≠τkw(τk +)=ψk(w(τk))t=τk,w(τ0)=w0≥0 is the comparison system of (3).Remark 1:
With the above assumption it is found that the trivial solutions of equations (3) and (6) are identical for all time except for the discrete set {τk}.Theorem 1
Let g(t,w)=λ·(t)w, λ∈C1[R+,R+], ψk(w)=dkw, dk≥0, k=1,2,….
Then the origin of system (3) is asymptotically stable if the conditions
there exists a γ>1 such that λ(τk+1)+ln(γdk)≤λ(τk)
λ·(t)≥0 are satisfied.

Chen hyper-chaotic system is described as follows (Yan, 2005), (7) {x·=a(y-x)+wy·=dx+cy-xzz·=xy-bzw·=yz+rw where x,y,z and w are state variable and a,d,c,b,r are real constants. When a=35, b=3,c=12,d=7 and 0.085<r≤0.798, system (8) exhibits a hyper-chaotic behavior as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Typical dynamical behaviors of system (7): (a) Projection in (x,y,z) space; (b) Projection in (x,y,w) space; (c) Projection in (x,z,w) space; (d) Projection in (y,z,w) space, when r=0.5.

Lu·· hyper-chaotic system is described as follows (Lorenz et al., 2006), (8) {x·=a1(y-x)+wy·=c1y-xzz·=xy-b1zw·=xz+r1w where x,y,z and w are state variable and a1,c1,b1,r1 are real constants. When a1=36, b1=3,c1=20 and -1.35<r1≤1.3,system (8) exhibits a hyper-chaotic behavior as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Typical dynamical behaviors of system (7): (a) Projection in (x,y,z) space; (b) Projection in (x,y,w) space; (c) Projection in (x,z,w)space; (d) Projection in (y,z,w) space, when r1=0.5.

The object of this work is to study impulsive synchronization between the above hyperchaotic systems with a scaling factor. The authors will show that the system (8) becomes an impulsive system with the adaptive control.

sec.title: 3. The scheme for impulsive synchronization
sec.p:
Consider Chen hyper-chaotic system as the drive system and Lu·· hyper-chaotic system with impulse as the response system. The drive system is the system (7). The response system is given by (9) {x·1=a1(y1-x1)+w1+u1y·1=c1y1-x1z1+u2z·1=x1y1-b1z1+u3w·1=x1z1+r1w1+u4 ,t≠τk, (x1(τk +)y1(τk +)z1(τk +)w1(τk +) )=M (x1(τk)-αx(τk)y1(τk)-αy(τk)z1(τk)-αz(τk)w1(τk)-αw(τk) )+ (x1(τk)y1(τk)z1(τk)w1(τk) ), where U=(u1,u2,u3,u4)T is the controller vector, α≠0 is a real constant and M is a 4-order matrix. Let d1=λmax((I+M)T(I+M)) where I denotes the identity matrix and λmax(A) denotes the largest eigenvalue of the positive definite matrix A. For the sake of convenience, the system (7) is rewritten as (10)X·=f(X)+F(X)P, where X·Δ= (x·y·z·w· ), f(X)=Δ (w-xzxyyz ),}
F(X)=Δ (y-x00000xy00000-z00000w ), PΔ= (adcbr ). Moreover the system (9) is denoted as (11)Y·=g(Y)+G(Y)Θ+U,t≠τk,Y(τk +) =M(Y(τk)-αX(τk))+Y(τk) where Y·=Δ (x·1y·1z·1w·1 ),g(Y)=Δ (w1-x1z1x1y1x1z1 ),G(Y)=Δ (y1-x10000y10000-z10000w1 ),Θ=Δ (a1c1b1r1 ),andY(τk)=Δ (x1(τk)y1(τk)z1(τk)w1(τk) )= (x1(τk -)y1(τk -)z1(τk -)w1(τk -) ).

The error state vector (12)e(t)=Y(t)-αX(t) satisfies (13)e·(t)=Y·(t)-αX·(t),t≠τke(τk +)=Me(τk)+e(τk),t=τk. Let the adaptive control (14)U=-g(Y)+αf(X)+αF(X)P∧-G(Y)Θ∧+Ωe where Ω is 4-order positive definite matrix, P∧=(a∧,b∧,c∧,d∧,r∧)T and Θ∧=(a∧1,c∧1,b∧1,r∧1)T are the vectors of estimated parameters. They satisfy these update laws as following, (15)∧·P=-αFT(X)e-P~∧·Θ=GT(Y)e-Θ~,t≠τk,P∧(τk +)=d2P∧(τk)+(1-d2)PΘ~(τk +)=d3Θ∧(τk)+(1-d3)Θ where P~=P∧-P,Θ~=Θ∧-Θ, and d2,d3 are positive constants.

Definition 1(IS): For the above systems (10) and (11), it is said that they are the impulsive synchronization about the scaling factor α. If there exists the updating laws of the estimated parameters such that the error vector e(t) converges to zero for large enough t, i.e. (16)limt→+∞ ‖e(t) ‖=limt→+∞ ‖y(t)-αx(t) ‖=0, then the states of the response system and the drive system about the scaling factor α are synchronized asymptotically.Theorem 2:
Let e(t)=y(t)-αx(t) for the drive system (7) and the response system (9). r= max(1,λmax(Ω)) and d=max(d1,d2,d3). If the active control U(x,y) is given by equation (11) and the updating laws of the estimated parameters are given by equation (15), and (17)r(τk+1-τk)+ln(γd)≤0,γ>1, then limt→+∞ ‖e(t) ‖=limt→+∞ ‖y(t)-αx(t) ‖=0, that is to say, the impulsive synchronization occurs between the drive system (10) and the response system (11) with respect to the scaling factor α.Proof:
Construct a positive Lyapunov function candidate in the form of
For t≠τk, there follows (18)D+V(t,e)=-(G(y)Θ~)Te+α(F(x)P~)Te+eTΩe +Θ~T(G(y))Te-αP~T(F(x))Te =eTΩe≤rV(t,e).
For t=τk, there follows (19)V(τk,e+Me)=12((e+Me)T(e+Me)+d2P~TP~ +d3Θ~TΘ~)=eT(I+M)T(I+M)e +d2P~TP~+d3Θ~TΘ~≤d(eT(τk)e(τk) +P~T(τk)P~(τk)+Θ~T(τk)Θ~(τk)) =dV(τk,e).
Let λ·(t)=r,dk≤d,k=1,2,…. Then it follows from theorem 1 that the origin of the error system (13) is asymptotically stable. This completes the proof. □

Let Ω=diag{r1,r2,r3,r4}, M=diag{m1,m2,m3,m4} and d2=d3=maxi(1+mi)2 where ri>0,i=1,2,3,4. The following corollary holds.Corollary 1:
Let r=maxi(ri),ri≥1,i=1,2,3,4 and d=d1=d2=d3. Let the impulses be equidistant and separated by interval Δ. Assume that there exists γ>1 such that (20)rΔ+ln(γd)≤0. then the origin of the error system (13) is asymptotically stable.Remark 2:
Ho et al. (2006) studied the issue of controlling projective synchronization (PS) by using a continuous synchronization scheme with the update laws of unknown parameters, in which signals are transmitted continuously to the response systems such that the PS, with desired scaling factor, can be realized. In this paper, the same issue has been considered, however by using the impulsive synchronization scheme. The proposed impulsive synchronization scheme is more practicable than ever.

sec.title: 4. An illustrative example
sec.p: To simplify the analysis, M is set. The parameters of the drive system are selected and the response system as above. The initial values of two systems are x1(0)=5.0, x2(0)=8.0, x3(0)=0.1, x4(0)=0.3 and y1(0)=3.0, y2(0)=4.0, y3(0)=5.0, y4(0)=5.0. The estimated parameters start from a∧(0)=b∧(0)=c∧(0)=d∧(0)=a∧1(0)=c∧1(0)=b∧1(0) =r∧1(0)=1.0. Let γ=2, Δ=0.01, r=1, and m1=m2=m3=m4=-1.2, then d=0.04. It has rΔ+ln(γd)=0.01+ln(0.08)<0. Let α=2. The error system is e(t)=Y(t)-2X(t).

From equation (14), the response system (11) is (21)Y·=2f(X)+2F(X)P∧-G(Y)Θ~+Ωe,t≠τk,Y(τk +)=-0.2Y(τk)+2.4X(τk). The update laws of these parameters are (22)∧·P=-2FT(X)e-P~∧·Θ=GT(Y)e-Θ~,t≠τk,P∧(τk +)=0.2P∧(τk)+0.8PΘ~(τk +)=0.2Θ∧(τk)+0.8Θ.

The four impulsive synchronization error states for the systems (10) and (21) are shown in Figure 3. The dynamics of the parameters’ estimation are plotted in Figure 4. Figure 3.
Dynamics of synchronization errors states for systems (10) and (21) with time t.
Figure 4.
Estimate values of parameters with the update rule of these parameters. (a) a, b, c, d and r, (b) a1, b1, c1, and r1.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the impulsive synchronization between two different hyper-chaotic systems with unknown parameters are investigated and a general scheme for the impulsive synchronization proposed, based on the impulsive differential stability theorem. It is easy and convenient to use this scheme, which is more robust.
Furthermore, the numerical simulation has been given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) (grant numbers 11001215 and 11072182).
